org.gearvrf

Class GVRScene

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.gearvrf.GVRHybridObject
      • org.gearvrf.GVRScene
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    IEventReceiver, PrettyPrint, IScriptable

    public class GVRScene
extends GVRHybridObject
implements PrettyPrint, IScriptable, IEventReceiver
    Contains a the hierarchy of visible objects, a camera and processes events. The scene receives events defined in ISceneEvents and IPickEvents. To add a listener to these events, use the following code: 
         ISceneEvents mySceneEventListener = new ISceneEvents() {
         ...
     };
     getEventReceiver().addListener(mySceneEventListener);
    The scene graph is a hierarchy with all the objects to display. It has a single root and one main camera rig. Each visible object, or node, in the scene graph is a GVRSceneObject with a GVRTransform component that places and orients it in space with respect to it's parent node. A node can have multiple children, and a child inherits the concatenation of all of it's ancestors transformations.
    See Also:
    GVRSceneObject, GVRTransform, IEventReceiver, ISceneEvents

      protected class  GVRScene.ShaderBinder

        public GVRSceneObject getRoot()

        Returns:
        top level scene object.
        See Also:

        See Also:

      • getWholeSceneObjects

        public GVRSceneObject[] getWholeSceneObjects()
        Returns:
        The flattened hierarchy of objects as an array. This function is inefficient if your hierarchy is large and should not be called per frame (in onStep).

        Returns:

        public GVRSceneObject getSceneObjectByName(java.lang.String name)
        Performs case-sensitive depth-first search
        Parameters:
        name -
        Returns:
        first match in the graph; null if nothing was found or name was null/empty; in case there might be multiple matches consider using getSceneObjectsByName

      • setPickVisible

        public void setPickVisible(boolean flag)
        Enable / disable picking of visible objects. Picking only visible objects is enabled by default. Only objects that can be seen will be pickable by GVRPicker. Disable this feature if you want to be able to pick stuff the viewer cannot see.
        Parameters:
        flag - true to enable pick only visible, false to enable pick all colliders
        See Also:
        GVRPicker

      • export

        public void export(java.lang.String filepath)
        Exports the scene to the given file path at some of the following supported formats: Collada ( .dae ) Wavefront Object ( .obj ) Stereolithography ( .stl ) Stanford Polygon Library ( .ply ) The current supported formats are the same supported by Assimp library. It will export according to file's extension.
        Parameters:
        filepath - Absolute file path to export the scene.

      • bindShaders

        public void bindShaders(GVRSceneObject root)
        Bind the correct vertex and fragment shaders on the given hierarchy. This function sets the shader template for all the GVRRenderData components in the input hierarchy (but does not construct vertex and fragment shaders.) If new assets are loaded that add lights to the scene after initialization, bindShaders may need to be called again to regenerate the correct shaders for the new lighting conditions. This function is called whenever a scene object is added at the root of the scene.
        See Also:
        GVRRenderData.bindShader(GVRScene), GVRShaderTemplate, addSceneObject(GVRSceneObject)

      • getLightList

        public GVRLightBase[] getLightList()
        Get the list of lights used by this scene. This list is maintained by GearVRF by gathering the lights attached to the scene objects in the scene.
        Returns:
        array of lights or null if no lights in scene.

                              GVRTexture texture,
                              GVRShaderId shaderId)

        Parameters:
        key - Name of the texture. Common texture names are "main", "lightmap", etc.
        texture - The texture atlas
        shaderId - The shader to render the texture atlas.

      • setBackgroundColor

        public final void setBackgroundColor(float r,
                                     float g,
                                     float b,
                                     float a)
        Sets the background color of the scene. If you don't set the background color, the default is an opaque black. Meaningful parameter values are from 0 to 1, inclusive: values < 0 are clamped to 0; values > 1 are clamped to 1. Pass -1 for all parameters to disable the background color. If you do know you don't want the corresponding glClear call then you can use these special values to skip it.
